p: In human females, the ovarian reserve is established during fetal development and is gradually depleted until menopause ( Fig. 1-Female). The DNA damage response and the repair capacity of oocytes have been proposed to regulate this depletion of the ovarian reserve, resulting in menopause [58]. Human oocytes are highly sensitive to DNA damaging agents, such as those used during chemotherapy and a plethora of mouse studies have been conducted to assess effects of chemotherapy on female fertility (reviewed in [71]). This has led to programs for fertility preservation in women prior to initiating the gonadotoxic treatment [72], [73].
